awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Morphological and Functional Correlates of Variation in the Human Longitudinal Arch
awd_abstract_narration:
The longitudinal arch is considered to be a unique adaptation of the human foot that is crucial for proper foot function. During bipedal walking, the arch supports the weight of the body and transforms the foot into a propulsive lever. Human arch height varies, however, along a continuum from flat to very arched (often asymptomatically), which questions the notion that a well-developed arch is essential for healthy foot function. Our understanding of this variation is incomplete; more specifically, research is lacking in appreciation for the degree to which variation in foot bones contributes to variation in arch height, as well as how the arch structure seen in modern humans reflects the course of human evolutionary history. 

This dissertation project by doctoral student Amber Heard-Booth (under the supervision of Dr. Liza Shapiro, University of Texas at Austin) aims to improve our knowledge of the evolutionary history of the longitudinal arch so that we may more thoroughly understand the basis for its variation among modern humans. The research will 1) identify foot bone features that directly contribute to longitudinal arch height; 2) link these bony features to the way in which the foot supports body weight (plantar pressure); and 3) use this information to estimate arch height and reconstruct foot loading from the foot fossils of hominins (i.e., bipedal human ancestors). The relationship between foot bones, arch height, and plantar pressure will be assessed by studying both foot bone development in archaeological samples and the development of the arch in living children; as such, it represents the first to take an ontogenetic perspective and to fully utilize a sample of human feet known to vary in arch height. The relationship among these variables also will be investigated in an adult sample of humans using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and plantar pressure data. 

By contributing knowledge on the relationship between foot bone form and function in developing and adult human feet, this project will inform clinicians' understanding of the range of variation in arch development, which may help assess need for orthotics, while understanding how variation in arch height is linked to plantar pressure will help clinicians choose interventions to prevent pressure-related injuries. The research also fosters scientific education through provision of research opportunities to students at The University of Texas, especially through engagement with an internship program that targets first-generation undergraduates.

por.por_cntn:
The longitudinal arch is a unique structure of the human foot that is an important adaptation for bipedal walking and running. For decades, researchers studying human evolution have looked at the fossilized foot bones of human ancestors to determine whether these individuals had a longitudinally-arched foot. Human ancestors whose feet possessed a longitudinal arch would have (presumably) walked with a bipedal gait that was biomechanically-similar to that of our own, marking an important transition in human evolution. Currently, there are different opinions about whether select human ancestors had a longitudinal arch and thus a more modern human-like bipedal gait. The goal of this study was to improve our understanding of how variation in foot bone shape leads to variation in longitudinal arch height and foot function, and ultimately refine our ability to reconstruct foot shape (especially longitudinal arch height) and foot mechanics from fossilized foot bones.

First, this study used a sample of x-rays and MRI scans from modern human feet to test the relationship between foot bone shape and longitudinal arch height. While previous studies had suggested that features of select human foot bones were related to the longitudinal arch, none had tested whether variation in those features was directly related to variation in longitudinal arch height. Our study found that variation in features of the calcaneus (heel bone) and 3rd and 4th metatarsals is directly related to variation in longitudinal arch height. Using an archaeological sample of human skeletal remains, we further explored how the shapes of these particular bones change throughout growth of the foot. Because the longitudinal arch is a structure that develops throughout early childhood, we expected to see changes in foot bone shape that would correspond to the development of the arch. Our study confirmed that areas of the foot bones that are related to the structure of the longitudinal arch do, in fact, undergo changes throughout foot growth that are likely associated with the development (i.e., heightening) of the longitudinal arch.

Second, we collected plantar pressure (foot loading) and foot shape data on a sample of human subject volunteers to explore the relationship between foot shape and foot function. This data set was supplemented with a smaller data set that included foot shape, plantar pressure, and MRI imagery of the individuals' feet. Our study found that many humans have a more mobile or compliant midfoot region (under the longitudinal arch region) than is commonly reported in the clinical literature, and that midfoot compliance increases with the speed of an individual's gait. In other words, one's midfoot is more likely to be compliant during jogging or running than during walking, especially along the outside (lateral) margin. In addition to speed, individuals with longer and wider feet tend to experience greater lateral midfoot compliance than those with short and narrow feet.

In addition to these findings, the results of our study also highlight the complexity of the longitudinal arch. Because the arch is comprised of many bony elements and soft tissue structures, there is not a one-to-one fit between the shape of a single foot bone and the resulting height of the longitudinal arch. Two individuals could have similarly-shaped bones, but different arch heights; or, different shaped bones, but similar arch heights. Therefore, researchers who interpret foot fossils from human ancestors should avoid making very general statements about the individual's longitudinal arch height and subsequent foot function.
